title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
What is the motor system

The motor system allows the nervous system to generate movement. It transforms goals and intentions into coordinated muscle activity.




Producing movement requires:

Selecting an action

Planning its structure

Executing motor commands

Monitoring outcomes

These processes are distributed across multiple brain regions.



Key components of the motor system include:

Motor cortex
Basal ganglia

Cerebellum
Brainstem

Spinal cord

They interact continuously during movement.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Primary motor cortex

The primary motor cortex (M1) is the main cortical output of the motor system. It is located in the frontal lobe, anterior to somatosensory cortex. Neurons in M1 send commands toward the spinal cord.

Primary motor cortex is organized somatotopically. Different body parts are represented in different cortical regions. Fine motor control occupies more cortical space.



Encode patterns of movement such as:

Direction

Force

Coordination

Movement emerges from population activity.



Signals from motor cortex descend to the spinal cord. These pathways convey voluntary motor commands. Control is largely contralateral.


The spinal cord is the main site of motor execution. It integrates descending commands with sensory input.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
From cortex to muscle



Lower motor neurons reside in the ventral horn of the spinal cord. They are the final common pathway for movement. Their axons exit the CNS to innervate muscles.


Motor commands travel from:

Motor cortex

Through descending pathways

To spinal motor neurons

To muscle fibers

This pathway transforms intention into force.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
M1 is not enough


Although M1 and the spinal cord can generate movement, They do not decide what movement to make. That requires additional motor areas.

Voluntary movement involves choices.
The nervous system must:

Select appropriate actions

Organize sequences

Suppress unwanted movements

Planning occurs before execution.



The supplementary motor area (SMA) supports internally generated actions.
It is critical for:

Self-initiated movement

Sequencing

Bimanual coordination

It organizes actions over time.

The premotor cortex contributes to planning movements guided by external cues. It links sensory information to motor commands. It prepares movements before they are executed.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: M1 is not enough

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Subcortical structures



The basal nuclei regulate whether an action is initiated.
They are involved in:

Selecting appropriate actions

Suppressing competing or unwanted actions

They do not generate movement or send commands to muscles.
Their role is to gate motor plans.



The cerebellum regulates how an action is executed.
It is involved in:

Coordination and timing

Error correction

Motor learning

It compares intended movement with actual outcome.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cortical damage



Damage to primary motor cortex produces:

Weakness or paralysis

Loss of fine voluntary control

Deficits on the contralateral side

Reflexes are generally preserved.



Damage to premotor cortex or supplementary motor area leads to:

Difficulty planning movements

Impaired sequencing or initiation

Apraxia despite preserved strength

The problem is planning, not execution.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Basal nuclei damage



Damage to the basal nuclei disrupts action selection.
This can result in:

Difficulty initiating movement

Excessive or involuntary movements

Strength is usually preserved.



Basal nuclei dysfunction in Parkinsonian disorders leads to:

Bradykinesia

Rigidity

Resting tremor

Movement is difficult to initiate, not to execute.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cerebellar damage



Damage to the cerebellum causes:

Poor coordination

Inaccurate movements

Timing deficits

Strength is preserved, but movement is imprecise.



Cerebellar ataxia:

Unsteady gait

Dysmetria

Intention tremor

Errors increase during movement.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Motor neuron lesions



Damage to upper motor neurons leads to:

Weakness

Increased muscle tone

Hyperreflexia

This reflects loss of inhibitory control.


Damage to lower motor neurons causes:

Flaccid paralysis

Muscle atrophy

Loss of reflexes

The final output pathway is disrupted.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: Spinal cord and peripheral nerve damage
text:
Spinal cord and peripheral nerve damage



Spinal cord lesions produce:

Weakness below the lesion

Loss of voluntary control

Patterned sensory and motor deficits

The level of the lesion matters.



Damage to peripheral nerves results in:

Weakness in specific muscles

Loss of reflexes

Sensory deficits in nerve territory

Deficits follow peripheral anatomy.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Organization of the Nervous System
The nervous system is organized into distinct anatomical and functional divisions. It is composed of interconnected networks that work in tight coordination to support vital, sensory, emotional, cognitive, and behavioral functions.



Anatomical division classifies the nervous system based on physical structures and location



Functional division classifies the nervous system based on the type of information processed

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Anatomical Directions



Rostral or Anterior: toward the front

Caudal or Posterior: toward the back



Dorsal: toward the top

Ventral: toward the bottom



Medial: toward the midline

Lateral: away from the midline

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Anatomical Planes


The Body can be sectioned along three main planes:

Sagittal: Divides left and right halves
Coronal: Divides rostral and caudal parts
Horizontal (or Axial or Transverse): Divides dorsal and ventral parts

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Online Brain Atlases



Allen Brain Atlas
An interactive collection of brain maps linking anatomy, genes, and function, developed by the Allen Institute.


Neurotorium
An interactive 3D brain atlas for exploring cortical and subcortical structures, designed for education and intuitive navigation.


eBrains
A collection of digital brain atlases integrated with neuroscience data and tools for exploration and analysis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
CNS & PNS


The nervous system is classically divided into two main anatomical components:

Central Nervous System (CNS)
Brain and spinal cord


Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)
Nerves and ganglia outside the CNS

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Central Nervous System (CNS)



The CNS includes:

Brain

Spinal cord




Neurons in the CNS are responsible for:

Sensory processing

Cognitive & Emotional processing
Behavioural output




The CNS is protected by bone, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)


The PNS includes:


Cranial & Spinal nerves

Autonomic NS

Somatic NS




Its main role is communication between the body and the CNS.


Information flows in two directions:

Afferent: From body to CNS
Efferent: From CNS to body

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Somatic nervous system


The somatic nervous system:

Efferent Signals

Skeletal muscles

Voluntary movement



Afferent Signals

Skin

Muscles and Joints

This includes the sense of touch, temperature, pain, and proprioception.



Activity in this system is usually under conscious perception and voluntary control.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Autonomic nervous system


The autonomic nervous system regulates internal physiology.

It controls:

Vital functions (Heart rate, breathing…)
Smooth muscle (Digestion, salivation…)
Glands (Hormones…)



Most autonomic activity occurs without conscious awareness. It is composed of two main branches: Sympathetic and Parasympathetic.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Sympathetic nervous system


The sympathetic nervous system prepares the body for action Fight or Flight Response.

Activation of the sympathetic system typically leads to:

Increased heart rate

Bronchodilation

Reduced digestive activity

Mobilization of glucose




Increase the Arousal level. These effects support physical and cognitive demands.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Parasympathetic nervous system


The parasympathetic nervous system promotes maintenance and recovery. Rest and Digest Response.

Activation of the parasympathetic system typically leads to:

Decreased heart rate

Increased digestive activity

Energy storage

Glandular secretion




Decrease the Arousal level. These effects support recovery and homeostasis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Major divisions of the brain


From a broad anatomical perspective, the brain is divided into:

Cerebrum (or Forebrain)
Midbrain & Cerebellum
Brainstem (Hindbrain)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The cerebrum


The cerebrum is divided into two hemispheres (Left and Right) The hemispheres are connected by large bundles of axons (Corpus Callosum).

It is responsible for:

Sensory perception

Voluntary movement

Cognition and language

Conscious awareness




Despite strong similarities, the two hemispheres are not functionally identical.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cerebral Cortex


The outer layer of the cerebrum is the cerebral cortex.

Folding pattern

Gyri Raised ridges of cortex
Sulci Grooves that separate gyri

This pattern increase surface area without increasing volume.


Each hemisphere is subdivided into lobes. The main lobes are: Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, Occipital

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Frontal lobe


The frontal lobe is located anterior to the central sulcus.
It is heavily involved in motor control and high-level cognition.

Primary roles

Voluntary movement

Planning and decision making

Executive control



Effects of damage

Motor dysfunctions
Changes in personality and social behavior

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Parietal lobe


The parietal lobe lies posterior to the central sulcus. It integrates sensory information to construct spatial and bodily representations.

Primary roles

Somatosensory processing

Spatial awareness (Propioception)
Integration of sensory modalities




Effects of damage

Impaired touch perception

Spatial Neglect, especially after right hemisphere damage

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Temporal lobe


The temporal lobe is located laterally, beneath the lateral sulcus. It is closely associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion.

Primary roles

Auditory perception

Language comprehension

Memory & Emotional processing



Effects of damage

Auditory perception deficits

Impaired language comprehension

Memory & emotional disturbances

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Occipital lobe


The occipital lobe is located at the posterior pole of the brain.
It is primarily dedicated to visual processing.

Primary roles

Visual perception

Processing of shape, motion, and color




Effects of damage

Partial or complete loss of vision

Visual field deficits

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Subcortical structures
Below the Cerebral Cortex we can find also another layer of (Subcortical) structures.

Major subcortical structures include:

Basal nuclei

Hippocampus

Amygdala



They are not visible from the surface but are critical for information processing.

They interact extensively with the cortex.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Basal nuclei


The basal nuclei are a group of interconnected nuclei. Including the dorsal striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen) and the ventral striatum (nucleus accumbens), the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, the substantia nigra, and the subthalamic nucleus.

They are best known for their role in:

Movement regulation

Action selection

Habit formation




Damage to these structures disrupts movement without causing paralysis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Hippocampus


The hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe.

It is essential for:

Formation memory and Contextual processing
Spatial navigation

Emotional regulation



Damage may impair the ability to form new long-term memories.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Amygdala


The amygdala is also located in the medial temporal lobe.

It plays a major role in:

Emotional processing

Threat detection

Assigning emotional value to stimuli




Damage to this structure may strongly influence learning and memory under emotional conditions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Diencephalon


The diencephalon lies beneath the cerebrum.
It serves as a critical interface between cortical and subcortical systems.
Major components include:

Thalamus

Hypothalamus

Epithalamus

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Thalamus


The thalamus is often described as a relay station.
Most sensory information passes through it on the way to cortex.

However, it is not a passive relay. It actively shapes and modulates information flow.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Hypothalamus


The hypothalamus is a group of different nuclei, small but functionally powerful.

It regulates:

Homeostasis

Autonomic nervous system activity

Hormone release

Motivated behaviors




It forms a major link between the nervous and endocrine systems.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Brainstem


The brainstem connects the brain to the spinal cord.
It is essential for survival.

It controls basic functions such as:

Breathing

Heart rate

Sleep and arousal

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Brainstem subdivisions


The brainstem is divided into three major parts:


Midbrain

Pons

Medulla




Each contains nuclei and pathways critical for life.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cerebellum


The cerebellum lies posterior to the brainstem.

It is involved in:

Coordination of movement

Timing

Motor learning




Damage does not prevent movement, but makes it inaccurate and unstable.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cranial nerves
Cranial nerves are part of the peripheral nervous system. They connect directly to the brain.

Most cranial nerves enter or exit the CNS at the brainstem (except olfactory and optic nerves).


There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves. Numbered using Roman numerals I to XII .


Cranial nerves can be classified by function:

Sensory

Motor

Mixed (sensory and motor)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cranial nerves





Sensory
Motor
Mixed




Olfactory I
Oculomotor III
Trigeminal V


Optic II
Trochlear IV
Facial VII


Vestibulocochlear VII
Abducens VI
Glossopharyngeal IX



Accessory XI
Vagus X



Hypoglossal XII





The Vagus nerve X is unique. It provides extensive parasympathetic innervation to thoracic and abdominal organs. It is a major pathway for autonomic communication between brain and body.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The spinal cord
The spinal cord is part of the central nervous system. It serves as the main communication pathway between the brain and the body, through the spinal nerves. It also performs important processing independently of the brain.



Grouped into regions: Cervical, Thoracic, Lumbar, Sacral


Spinal nerves connect to the cord via two roots:

Dorsal root Carries sensory information into the spinal cord
Ventral root Carries motor commands out of the spinal cord

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: Self-check

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Movement


Neurons communicate using electrical signals.
These signals exist because ions move across cell membranes.
Understanding ion movement is the foundation for:

Electrical signaling
Membrane potential
Action potentials
Synaptic transmission

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. What Is an Ion?


An ion is an atom or molecule with an electrical charge.

Positive charge → cation

Negative charge → anion

In neuroscience, the most important ions are:

Sodium (Na⁺)
Potassium (K⁺)
Chloride (Cl⁻)
Calcium (Ca²⁺)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: 2. Why Charges Matter in the Brain
text:
2. Why Charges Matter in the Brain
Electrical signals arise because:

Ions carry charge
Neurons separate charges across membranes
Differences in charge create electrical forces


No electricity → no neural signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. The Neuronal Membrane


The neuron is surrounded by a lipid bilayer membrane.
Key properties:

Electrically insulating
Impermeable to most ions

This separation is essential for signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Channels


Ion channels are proteins embedded in the membrane.
They:

Allow specific ions to cross
Are selective (not all ions can pass)
Can open or close


Ion movement only occurs through these channels.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Channel Selectivity


Ion channels are selective because:

Ions differ in size
Ions differ in charge
Channel pores are highly specific

Example:

Sodium channels allow Na⁺ but not K⁺
Potassium channels allow K⁺ but not Na⁺

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Two Forces Acting on Ions
Ion movement depends on two forces:

Diffusion

Electrical attraction or repulsion


The combined effect determines ion flow.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Diffusion


Diffusion is movement from:





flowchart LR
  A[High concentration]
  B[Low concentration]

  A -->|Net flow| B
  B -. No net flow .-> A
  style A fill:#2b2b2b,stroke:#67bdfb,color:#e6e6e6
  style B fill:#2b2b2b,stroke:#67bdfb,color:#e6e6e6
  linkStyle default stroke:#bbbbbb,stroke-width:2px






If more Na⁺ ions are outside the neuron than inside, Na⁺ tends to move inward.

It does not require energy.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Electrical Forces


Charged particles are influenced by:

Opposite charges attract
Same charges repel

A negatively charged interior attracts positive ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Electrochemical Gradient
The electrochemical gradient combines:

Chemical gradient (diffusion)
Electrical gradient (charge)

Ion movement depends on both at the same time.
This is the key principle of neural signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Sodium Ions (Na⁺)
Typically:

High Na⁺ outside the neuron
Low Na⁺ inside
Inside of neuron is negatively charged


Both diffusion and electrical forces push Na⁺ inward.


The inside of the neuron (and cells in general) is negative mainly because of large amount of anions inside the cell like proteins and other large organic anions (phosphates, metabolites).

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Potassium Ions (K⁺)

High K⁺ inside the neuron
Low K⁺ outside
Electrical force pulls K⁺ inward
Diffusion pushes K⁺ outward


Here the diffusion force in higher that the electical force an K⁺ flux tends to go outward

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺)

Very low concentration inside neurons
Strong positive electrical charge
Acts as both an ion and a signaling molecule


Opening Ca²⁺ channels causes a inward flux of Ca²⁺ ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Movement Is Passive
Ion movement through channels:

Does not require energy
Is driven by electrochemical gradients


But maintaining the gradients require energy! The gradients are maintained by specific proteins called pumps that can move ions against their gradients.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Membrane Voltage


The neuron’s membrane separates electrical charges.
This separation creates a quantity called membrane voltage.

Voltage is a difference in electrical potential
It tells us how strong the electrical force is
It is measured across the membrane, not inside the cell


Voltage is not a substance and not a force.
It is a measure of how much electrical energy is available to move ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Which Ion Dominates?
The influence of an ion depends on:

Permeability, a measure of how easily a given ion can cross the membrane through its channels and is given by the number of ions for that channel are open.

At rest, neuronal membranes are:

Highly permeable to \(K^+\)
Weakly permeable to \(Na^+\)
Moderately permeable to \(Cl^-\)


In most neurons resting membrane potential is \(\approx -65\,\mathrm{mV}\). This reflects potassium dominance at rest.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Voltage Change
If channels open for an ion, the membrane potential changes. If a positive ion moves inside the cell, the membrane potential becomes less negative; if it moves outside, it becomes more negative. For negative ions, the effect is reversed.



Example: Opening Sodium Channels
If \(Na^+\) channels open:

\(Na^+\) enters the cell
Membrane potential becomes less negative

This process is called depolarization.



Example: Opening Potassium Channels
If \(K^+\) channels open:

\(K^+\) leaves the cell
Membrane potential becomes more negative

This process is called hyperpolarization.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. From Steady Voltage to Signals
Neurons use changes in membrane potential as signals.
These changes can be:

Small or large (millivolts )
Slow or fast (milliseconds)
Local or long-range (micrometers to meters)


Two main types exist:

Graded potentials
Action potentials

They differ in origin, size, and function.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Graded Potentials

Graded potential: local change in membrane potential whose magnitude depends on the strength of the stimulus.



Key properties:

Amplitude varies continuously
Can be depolarizing or hyperpolarizing
Spread passively
Become smaller with distance



This decay is due to:

Membrane resistance
Cytoplasmic resistance



They are common in:

Dendrites
Soma

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Integration of Graded Potentials


Multiple graded potentials can:

Add together in space (spatial summation)
Add together in time (temporal summation)

Integration mainly occurs at:

The cell body
The axon initial segment (axon hillock)


Neurons continuously integrate incoming signals.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Action Potentials


If depolarization is strong enough:

A critical voltage is reached
A different electrical event is triggered

This voltage is called the threshold. Potentials beyond the threshold trigger Action Potentials.

Action potential: A large, rapid, and stereotyped change in membrane potential, originated at the level of the axon hillock, that propagates along the axon.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Why Action Potentials Are Needed



Graded potentials decay with distance.

To communicate over long axons, neurons need:

A signal that does not fade
A reliable, all-or-none event

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Membrane Proteins and Transport
The lipid bilayer is electrically insulating. Ions can cross the membrane only through membrane proteins.
Membrane transport proteins fall into two broad categories:

Channels
Transporters (carriers and pumps)


Ion channel: A protein that forms a continuous aqueous pathway across the membrane, allowing ions to move down their electrochemical gradient.
Properties:

Do not use metabolic energy (passive)
Do not move ions against gradients (no energy)
Selective to specific Ions

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Channel Gating


Ion channels are not static holes.
They fluctuate between:

Closed states
Open states


Channels can be gated by different physical signals:

Chemical binding (ligand-gated - e.g. Neurotransmitters)
Mechanical deformation (mechanosensitive)
Membrane voltage (voltage-gated - activated when the membrane cross a specific voltage)




Gating: The process by which an ion channel switches between open and closed states.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Graded Potentials and Channels
During Graded Potentials:

Passive channels remain unchanged
Voltage-gated channels remain mostly closed


Voltage changes are passive and proportional to input and decay over space-time.

When depolarization is small:

A few voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channels open
Resulting \(Na^+\) influx is weak
Passive \(K^+\) currents counteract depolarization

The voltage relaxes back to rest.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Threshold Crossing
At threshold:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channel opening becomes significant
\(Na^+\) influx exceeds opposing currents
Depolarization accelerates

This marks the transition from passive to active behavior.

Once threshold is crossed:

Many \(Na^+\) channels open rapidly
Membrane permeability to \(Na^+\) increases sharply
Voltage changes are no longer passive

The action potential is initiated.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. During the Action Potential


During the spike:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channels open, then inactivate
Voltage-gated \(K^+\) channels open with delay

Voltage is dominated by voltage-gated dynamics.
After the action potential:

\(Na^+\) channels recover from inactivation
\(K^+\) channels close
Passive channels dominate again









Inactivation: A state in which a voltage-gated channel is closed and temporarily unable to reopen, even though the membrane is still depolarized.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Refractory Period


After an action potential, the neuron cannot immediately fire another spike.

Refractory period: A time interval following an action potential during which the neuron’s ability to generate another action potential is reduced or absent.

This phase is caused purely by Na⁺ channel inactivation.
Refractory periods ensure that:

Action potentials propagate in one direction
Spikes are separated in time (neural code)
Maximum firing frequency is limited

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Axon Diameter and Conduction Speed
The speed of action potential propagation depends on axon geometry.
Larger axons:

Have lower internal (axial) resistance
Allow local currents to spread more easily
Depolarize adjacent membrane faster

As a result, action potentials propagate faster in thicker axons.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Myelination


Many axons, especially long ones, are wrapped in myelin, a multilayered insulating sheath formed by glial cells. This ensures that the signal reaches its destination.
Myelination is not continuous along the axon. Axons contain regularly spaced gaps called nodes of Ranvier.

At nodes:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) and \(K^+\) channels are highly concentrated
Action potentials are regenerated
Saltatory conduction (the action potential jumps from one node to the other)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: 2. Self-check

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Index

Welcome to the course! This part of the course introduces the foundations of neuroscience. We will cover basic principles of neurobiology,
an introduction to neurophysiology, and the core concepts needed to understand how the nervous system works, from neurons to systems.

Chapters




Introduction
Neuron
Neuronal Communication
Organization of the Nervous System
Sensory Systems





Motor System

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. What Is Neuroscience?


Neuroscience asks a simple question:
How does the brain produce behavior?

Studies the Central (brain and spinal cord) and Peripheral (somatic, autonomic and enteric) nervous systems

Connects biology, psychology, physics, engineering, and philosophy

Goal of this course: build intuition about how the nervous system works, without assuming prior biology knowledge.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. What Is a Neuron?


Neurons are the basic units of the brain.
Their main function is to send electrical signals over short and long distances.
They are electrically and chemically excitable. The function of a neuron depends on its structure.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Major Parts of the Neuron



Dendrites

Cell body (soma)
Axon hillock
Axon
Presynaptic terminal These components determine how signals are received, processed, and transmitted.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Diagram: Typical Neuron


A neuron has:
- Branching dendrites
- A soma with nucleus
- A long axon
- Terminal branches forming synapses

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Dendrites



Branch out from the soma

Primary targets of incoming signals

The number of dendrites influences how many inputs the neuron can receive

Often contain spines, which increase surface area for synaptic contact

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Cell Body (Soma)



Contains nucleus and organelles

Integrates incoming signals from dendrites

Biochemistry of the cell shapes its excitability and response properties

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. The Nucleus and DNA



The nucleus contains the cell’s DNA
DNA is a long chain of nucleotides
Nucleotides form genes


Genes are instructions for building cellular components

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. From Genes to Proteins



Genes encode proteins
Proteins are chains of amino acids
The sequence of nucleotides determines:

The sequence of amino acids
The structure and function of the protein



Proteins are the working molecules of the cell

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Axon Hillock



Junction between soma and axon

Location where action potentials are initiated

Sensitive to the summed electrical inputs from dendrites and soma

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. The Axon



Conducts electrical signals over long distances

May be myelinated to increase conduction speed

Can branch extensively

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Presynaptic Terminal



End of the axon

Releases neurotransmitter onto postsynaptic cells

Forms multiple terminals for communication with many neurons

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Neurons Communicate Electrically and Chemically

Electrical signals travel along the axon.

Chemical signals (neurotransmitters) are released at the synapse.

This dual mode of signaling enables fast and flexible communication.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Structure Influences Function


Examples: - More dendrites → more inputs
- Axon myelination → faster conduction
- Terminal branching → more downstream targets
Form and function are tightly linked in neuronal physiology.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Neuron Diversity (Overview)
Neurons vary in:

Size

Shape

Dendritic complexity

Axon length

Neurotransmitter type

This diversity supports specialized functions across the nervous system.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Summary of Key Concepts

Neurons are the fundamental signaling units of the nervous system

Structure determines function

Signals are electrical within neurons and chemical between them

Dendrites receive, soma integrates, axon transmits, terminals communicate

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Self-Check Questions

Which part of the neuron initiates the action potential?

How do dendritic spines enhance synaptic communication?

Why does neuron structure influence neuron function?

Which part releases neurotransmitter?

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Synaptic Communication
Neurons transmit information to other neurons and target cells using specialized compartments called Synapses. A Synapse is a specialized junction where a neuron communicates with another neuron (or another cell).

IMPORTANT: In synapses, neurons are not physically continous, but there is a gap called Synaptic Cleft




Three main components:

Presynaptic compartment (or terminal)
Synaptic cleft

Postsynaptic compartment (or spine)




Synapses allow:

Directional signaling

Signal modulation

Integration of multiple inputs

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Presynaptic Events



Action potential arrives at terminal
Membrane depolarization
Opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels
Ca²⁺ influx triggers vesicle fusion
Neurotransmitter released into synaptic cleft

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Synaptic Vesicles



Small membrane-bound organelles in the presynaptic terminal

Store neurotransmitters at high concentration

Cluster near active zones of the presynaptic membrane


Key properties:

Release occurs in discrete, quantal events
The release is mediated by SNARE proteins
Vesicles are recycled locally




Process:

SNAREs bring vesicle and presynaptic membranes close together

Ca²⁺ influx triggers final fusion step

Neurotransmitter released by exocytosis

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Postsynaptic Membrane


Contains neurotransmitter Receptors

Receptors can be of two main classes:

Ionotropic receptors

Ligand-gated ion channels
Fast responses

Metabotropic receptors

G-protein coupled
Slower but modulatory (long-lasting response)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Postsynaptic Events


Neurotransmitter binding produces graded signals of different types:

EPSP: Excitatory PostSynaptic Potential
IPSP: Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potential


Excitatory synapses:

Depolarize the membrane
Mediated by Na (or Ca²⁺ in special cases) influx

Inhibitory synapses:

Hyperpolarize or stabilize membrane potential
Mediated by Cl⁻ influx









Neurotransmitter action ends by:

Reuptake into presynaptic terminal
Enzymatic degradation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Neurotransmitters
Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers released at synapses
They transmit signals from a presynaptic neuron to a postsynaptic cell



Each neurotransmitter:

Is synthesized in the neuron
Is released in response to activity
Acts on specific receptors




Neurotransmitters can be grouped by function:

Excitatory
Inhibitory
Modulatory




The effect depends on the receptor, not only on the neurotransmitter

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Glutamate - Glu



Main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain


Increases neuronal excitability (EPSP)
Really abbundant in the brain


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. GABA



Main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain


Reduces neuronal excitability (IPSP)
Essential for network stability


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors (fast inhibition)
Metabotropic receptors (slow inhibition)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Acetylcholine - ACh



Acts as a Diffuse Projection System in the brain. This means that is produced in specific nuclei and projected throughout the brain. AKA: Cholinergic system

Involved in:

Muscle contraction
Vital and Cognitive functions


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Serotonin - 5-Ht



Acts as a Diffuse Projection System in the brain. This means that is produced in specific nuclei and projected throughout the brain. AKA: Serotoninergic system

Involved in:

Mood and Emotional processing
Vital functions including Sleep and Appetite


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Dopamine - DA



Acts as a Diffuse Projection System in the brain. This means that is produced in specific nuclei and projected throughout the brain. AKA: Dopaminergic system
Involved in:


Motivation, Learning and Reward
Movement control


Acts on:

Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Noradrenaline - NA



Or Norepinephrine. Acts as a Diffuse Projection System in the brain. This means that is produced in specific nuclei and projected throughout the brain. AKA: Noradrenergic System.

Involved in:

Arousal and Attention
Stress response


Acts on:

Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Adrenaline



Or Epinephrine. Less abundant in the Central Nervous System than other neurotransmitters. More Peripheral.

Involved in:

Arousal and Autonomic regulation
Stress response


Acts on:

Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Other Signaling Molecules
In addition to classical neurotransmitters, neurons use other chemical signals.
These molecules often act as modulators rather than fast transmitters



Neuropeptides

Endorphins

Pain, Reward, Stress regulation …

Oxytocin

Social, Maternal behavior …

Substance P

Pain, Inflammatory responses …





Other Signaling Systems

Endocannabinoids

Appetite, mood, and memory, Retrograde signaling ….

Nitric Oxide (NO)

Retrograde and Short-range signaling, Blood flow regulation …

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Receptors
Neurotransmitters act by binding to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane
Receptors determine the speed and effect of synaptic transmission



Ionotropic Receptors

Ligand-gated ion channels
Neurotransmitter binding directly opens the channel
Produce fast responses (milliseconds)




Metabotropic Receptors

Do not form ion channels
Coupled to intracellular signaling pathways
Neurotransmitter binding activates G-proteins
Effects are slower but longer-lasting

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Glutamate Ionotropic Receptors


Glutamate activates multiple ionotropic receptors, including:

AMPA receptors

Fast excitatory transmission
Allow Na⁺ influx
Main mediator of rapid excitation

NMDA receptors

Slower and Long-lasting kinetics
Permeable to Ca²⁺
Involved in synaptic plasticity

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. GABA Ionotropic Receptors


GABA-A receptors

Ionotropic inhibitory receptors
Allow Cl⁻ influx
Reduce neuronal excitability

Provide fast inhibition in neural circuits

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Metabotropic Receptors

Do not form ion channels
Coupled to intracellular singaling pathways
Neurotransmitter binding activates G-proteins
Effects are slower but longer-lasting


Signaling Pathway: chain of intracellular events where molecules relay messages from outside the cell to trigger specific internal responses like growth, division, or death

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs)



Modulate synaptic transmission
Regulate ion channel activity indirectly
Influence plasticity and excitability


Similar mechanisms apply to many modulatory systems systems, such as dopamine and serotonin


Neuromodulation is the process by which a neurotransmitter does not directly trigger a fast electrical signal, but instead changes how a neuron or a network responds to external inputs.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Position of the Synapse
Also the position of a synapse along a neuron matters, because neurons are not electrically uniform cables. Where a signal arrives strongly shapes what it can do.




Axo-dendritic

Axon contacts a dendrite (Most common type)
Often excitatory





Axo-somatic

Axon contacts the cell body
Strong influence on spike generation






Axo-axonic

Axon contacts another axon
Modulates neurotransmitter release

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Neurotransmitter Clearance
After release, neurotransmitters must be removed from the synaptic cleft
This ensures that synaptic signals are brief and precisely controlled

Reuptake

Neurotransmitter is transported back into the presynaptic terminal
Mediated by specific membrane transporters
Allows recycling of neurotransmitter molecules

Enzymatic Degradation

Neurotransmitter is broken down by enzymes in the synaptic cleft
Prevents prolonged receptor activation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Drugs and Neurotransmitter Clearance
Many drugs act by altering how neurotransmitters are removed from the synaptic cleft
By changing clearance, drugs modify the strength and duration of synaptic signaling.



Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs)

Block serotonin reuptake transporters
Increase serotonin availability at synapses

Used to treat:

Depression
Anxiety disorders

Effects develop slowly due to circuit-level adaptations



Cocaine

Blocks reuptake of:

Dopamine
Norepinephrine
Serotonin


Results in:

Strong increase in synaptic signaling
Enhanced reward and arousal
High addictive potential

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
In-Class Exercise - Items

Synapses are points where neurons are physically continuous

Neurotransmitter effects depend only on the neurotransmitter released

Ionotropic receptors mediate fast synaptic responses

NMDA receptors are permeable to calcium ions

GABA-A receptors are excitatory ion channels

Monoamines mainly act as neuromodulators

Endocannabinoids are released from presynaptic terminals

Neurotransmitter clearance helps limit synaptic signal duration

SSRIs reduce serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft

Axo-axonic synapses can modulate neurotransmitter release

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Answers and Explanations

False - Neurons are not physically continuous at synapses; they are separated by the synaptic cleft.
False - The effect depends on the receptor type activated, not only on the neurotransmitter.
True - Ionotropic receptors directly open ion channels and produce fast responses.
True - NMDA receptors are permeable to Ca²⁺ and play a key role in synaptic plasticity.
False - GABA-A receptors are inhibitory and typically allow Cl⁻ influx.
True - Monoamines mainly modulate neural circuits rather than driving fast synaptic transmission.
False - Endocannabinoids are released from postsynaptic neurons and act retrogradely.
True - Clearance mechanisms terminate signaling and preserve temporal precision.
False - SSRIs block serotonin reuptake, increasing its concentration in the synaptic cleft.
True - Axo-axonic synapses regulate neurotransmitter release rather than postsynaptic voltage.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Beyond the “Five Senses”
The idea that humans have only five senses is a historical simplification.

What we call a sense is any system that:

detects a specific form of energy or chemical signal
converts it into neural activity
provides information about the body or the environment


By this definition, the nervous system supports many parallel sensory channels, often operating outside awareness.

The brain does not experience “the world” directly.
It constructs reality from multiple specialized input streams, some obvious, some silent.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Additional Sensory Systems
Beyond vision, audition, smell, taste, and touch, the nervous system includes:



Equilibrioception (vestibular sense)
Signals head position and movement, supporting balance, posture, and stable vision.
Proprioception
Provides continuous information about limb position, muscle stretch, and joint angle, even with eyes closed.
Interoception
Monitors the internal state of the body, including heart rate, respiration, hunger, visceral pain, and arousal.



Nociception
Detection of harmful stimuli. It is not pain, which is a perceptual and emotional construct.
Thermoception
Sensing temperature changes.
Pruriception (Itch)
A distinct sensory modality, not just weak pain.
Chemoception (internal)
Detection of blood chemistry such as CO₂.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
What is a sensory system


A sensory system allows the nervous system to detect and process stimuli from the environment.

Each system is specialized for a particular form of energy or stimulus.

Despite their differences, sensory systems share common organizational principles.

Sensory Transduction
Sensory systems work by converting physical stimuli into neural signals. This process is called transduction.



Sensory receptors: Sensory transduction begins at sensory receptors.


Different receptors are tuned to different stimulus types:

Photoreceptors detect light

Mechanoreceptors detect touch and vibration

Chemoreceptors detect chemicals

Nociceptors detect damaging stimuli

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Sensory Neural Code


Sensory transduction begins at sensory receptors.

Receptor potentials
Sensory receptors generate receptor potentials, graded changes in membrane potential. Stronger stimuli generally produce larger receptor potentials. If threshold is reached, action potentials are generated.


Stimulus intensity is encoded in two main ways:

Firing rate of action potentials

Number of activated receptors




Receptive fields
A receptive field is the region of sensory space that influences a neuron.
Examples include:

A patch of skin

A region of the retina

A specific sound frequency

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Sensory pathways


Most sensory systems follow a common pathway:

Peripheral receptor

Entry into CNS

Relay through the thalamus

Projection to primary sensory cortex


The thalamus plays a central role in sensory processing. It does more than relay information. It actively modulates and organizes sensory signals before they reach cortex.



There is one exception the olfaction: The olfactory system does not relay through the thalamus, but the signal reaches cortex directly.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Primary sensory cortex


Each sensory system has a primary cortical area.

These areas:

Serve as the entry point for cortical processing

Receive organized sensory input

Preserve spatial relationships




Damage here produces modality-specific deficits.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Distributed processing


Perception does not arise in a single area.

Sensory information is processed across:

Primary cortex

Secondary areas

Association cortices




Perception is an emergent property of distributed networks.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Vision



The visual system responds to electromagnetic radiation in the visible spectrum.
Key properties of light include:

Wavelength

Intensity

These properties are transformed into neural signals by the retina.


A ‘sensory window’ is the part of a physical dimension that a biological system can detect. What lies outside the window is not perceived, but it still exists. Human vision : Sensitive roughly to wavelengths between ~400 nm (violet) and ~700 nm (red)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Anatomy of the eye



Light enters the eye through several structures:

Cornea

Pupil

Lens
Retina




The Retina is organized in layers. Light passes through several cell layers before reaching photoreceptors. Neural processing begins within the retina itself.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Photoreceptors



Photoreceptors are specialized cells that respond to light.


There are two main types:

Rods

Cones




Rods are highly sensitive to light. They are specialized for:

Low-light conditions (Night vision - Scotopic)
No color information




Cones are less sensitive to light. They are specialized for:

Daylight vision

Color perception

High spatial resolution

Humans typically have 3 cone types.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: The fovea and the Optic Nerve
text:
The fovea and the Optic Nerve



The fovea is a small region near the center of the retina. It contains a high density of cones. It provides the highest visual acuity.


In addition to photoreceptors, the retina contains:

Bipolar cells
Horizontal cells

Amacrine cells

Ganglion cells

These cells shape and refine visual signals.



The axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve.
This nerve carries visual information to the brain.
Where the optic nerve exits the retina, there are no photoreceptors. This creates the blind spot.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Retinal ganglion cells (RGC)



Retinal ganglion cells are the output neurons of the retina. They receive input indirectly from photoreceptors through bipolar and amacrine cells. Their axons form the optic nerve.


Retinal ganglion cell receptive fields are circular and organized into [2 regions]:

A central region

A surrounding region

Light affects these regions in opposite ways.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
RGC Receptive Field



In ON-center ganglion cells:

Light in the center increases firing

Light in the surround decreases firing


They respond best to a bright spot on a darker background.









In OFF-center ganglion cells:

Light in the center decreases firing

Light in the surround increases firing


They respond best to a dark spot on a brighter background.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
RGC Receptive Field

Uniform illumination produces weak responses. his makes the RGC sensitive to changes in relative illumination across space-time.




Center–surround organization emphasizes:

Contrast
Changes in light intensity

No relation with the absolute light levels




Center-surround receptive fields arise from retinal circuitry.
Key contributors include:

Bipolar cells

Horizontal cells

Amacrine cells

Lateral interactions are essential.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Visual acuity



Visual acuity refers to the ability to resolve fine spatial detail.


Visual acuity is constrained by multiple factors:

Density of photoreceptors in the retina

Size of receptive fields

Cortical magnification in visual cortex

Acuity is highest in the fovea and decreases toward the periphery.



Eye movements continuously place objects of interest onto high-acuity regions (Fovea).

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
From retina to the Brain



After retinal processing, visual information leaves the eye through the optic nerve. Each optic nerve carries information from one eye. At this stage, information is segregated by eye. The optic nerves meet at the optic chiasm. Here, some axons cross to the opposite side of the brain. This crossing is partial, not complete.


The Crossing Rule:

Axons from the nasal retina cross at the chiasm.
Axons from the temporal retina remain on the same side.

Each hemisphere receives information from the contralateral visual field.



Ipsilateral
Located on the same side of the body as the structure or reference point.
Contralateral
Located on the opposite side of the body relative to the structure or reference point.


After the chiasm:

Left hemisphere processes right visual field

Right hemisphere processes left visual field

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The thalamus



Beyond the chiasm, axons continue as the optic tract. Most optic tract fibers synapse in the thalamus. This relay is obligatory for conscious vision.


Visual information synapses in the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN).
The LGN:

Preserves retinal organization

Maintains separation of inputs (monocular)

Modulates signal flow to cortex

Receptive fields are similar to those of RGC (circular)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Input to V1



Axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus project to V1 (Primary Visual Cortex). These projections travel via the optic radiations. Arriving to the IV layer of V1. Each hemisphere represents the contralateral visual field.


V1 is organized retinotopically.
This means that:

Neighboring points in the retina

Map to neighboring points in cortex

Spatial relationships are preserved.



Cortical Magnification Factor:Retinotopy is not uniform.
The fovea occupies a disproportionately large area of V1.
This reflects:

High cone density

High visual acuity

Central vision is overrepresented.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
What V1 neurons encode



Neurons in V1 respond to simple visual features and start integrating the binocular input.


Features encoded:

Edges

Orientation

Spatial location
Binocularity from layer 2/3

V1 extracts structure from retinal input.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
V1 Receptive Fields



Neurons in primary visual cortex have receptive fields that differ from those in the retina. They are not circular! They are elongated and selective for specific visual features.


Each V1 neuron prefers a specific orientation. Rotation of the stimulus away from the preferred orientation reduces the response.








Even-symmetric receptive fields have:

Symmetric ON and OFF regions

Strong responses to bars

They respond best to a bright or dark line at the preferred orientation.


Odd-symmetric receptive fields have:

Asymmetric ON and OFF regions

Strong responses to edges

They are particularly sensitive to luminance transitions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
V1 Receptive Fields 2



Simple cells have:

Clearly defined ON and OFF subregions

Strong orientation selectivity

Sensitivity to exact stimulus position and polarity



Complex cells also show orientation selectivity.

Lack clearly separated ON and OFF regions

Are less sensitive to exact position

They integrate input over space.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A feedforward model of vision



In the feedforward models:

Simple features are combined into complex ones
Features become more abstract

Sensitivity to exact position decreases



Feedforward models are incomplete.
They do not fully explain:

Contextual effects

Attention

Visual illusions

Additional interactions are required.




Video

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Higher-order visual cortex

Beyond V1, visual information diverges. Multiple cortical areas specialize in different aspects of vision. These areas form distributed processing streams.


Visual processing splits into two dominant pathways:

Ventral stream

Dorsal stream

They differ in anatomy, function, and behavioral relevance.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The “what” and “where” pathways



The ventral stream runs from occipital to temporal cortex.
It is primarily involved in:

Object recognition

Shape and color processing

Face perception


It answers the question: What is it?




The dorsal stream runs from occipital to parietal cortex.
It is involved in:

Spatial localization

Motion processing

Visually guided actions


It answers the question: Where is it?

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Beyond what and where



The two-stream model is a simplification.
Modern views emphasize:

Interaction between streams

Feedback connections

Task-dependent processing

Vision is dynamic, not strictly hierarchical.


Higher-order areas send feedback to earlier visual cortex (top-down stream).

Attention

Contextual effects
Prediction

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The ventral stream and identity



Faces detection and recognition is a Holistic process. This means that faces are processed as integrated wholes.


A key region for face perception is the fusiform area of the temporal lobe.
It is involved in:

Recognizing individual faces

Discriminating subtle facial features



 Video

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Damage to the what pathway



Damage to ventral visual cortex can spare basic vision. Patients may see objects clearly but fail to identify or discriminate objects.


Prosopagnosia is a selective impairment in face recognition.
Affected individuals:

Can (or cannot, in severe cases) see faces

Cannot recognize faces

Other visual abilities are often preserved.



Individuals with prosopagnosia often rely on:

Voice

Clothing

Contextual cues

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
What prosopagnosia reveals



Prosopagnosia demonstrates that:

Face recognition is neurally specialized

Vision and recognition can dissociate

The higher order cortical areas can act as expert systems

Seeing is not the same as knowing.


An expert system is a neural network that:

Is highly selective

Encodes complex, meaningful patterns

Responds efficiently to familiar categories




We discriminate faces:

Rapidly (100-400 ms)
Automatically

With high precision



The grandmother neuron hypothesis proposes that:

A single neuron represents a specific, complex concept

For example, one neuron for your grandmother

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Problems with grandmother neurons



A strict grandmother neuron model would be:

Fragile to cell loss

Inflexible

Inefficient for representing many identities

Most neuroscientists reject this literal interpretation.


These neurons do not encode a single image. They respond to an abstract identity. They are better understood as:

Highly selective nodes

Within a distributed representation

Not isolated concept holders.



Higher-order cortex likely uses sparse coding.
This means:

Few neurons respond strongly

Many neurons contribute weakly

Representations are distributed but efficient

This balances specificity and robustness.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Spatial localization deficits



Damage to dorsal areas impairs:

Impaired perception of movement

Difficulty tracking moving objects

In extreme cases, motion appears fragmented or absent.


Akinetopsia, or motion blindness, is a rare condition linked to dorsal stream damage.
Patients perceive the world as a sequence of static snapshots.
Motion information fails to integrate over time.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The somatosensory system
The sense of touch allows the nervous system to detect mechanical stimulation of the body. Touch is not a single sense. It is a collection of specialized channels working together.



It provides information about:

Contact

Pressure

Vibration

Stretch

Touch is essential for interaction with the environment.








The somatosensory system includes multiple modalities:

Light touch

Pressure and vibration

Skin stretch

Proprioception

Pain and temperature

These modalities are detected by different receptor types.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Mechanoreceptors

Touch begins at mechanoreceptors. These receptors convert mechanical forces into neural signals. Each type is tuned to specific stimulus properties.




Key mechanoreceptors in the skin include:

Meissner corpuscles
Sensitive to motion and light touch
Merkel cells
Detect edges and fine detail
Pacinian corpuscles
Detect vibration
Ruffini endings
Detect skin stretch

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Spatial acuity



Each mechanoreceptor has a receptive field. This is the region of skin where stimulation affects that receptor. Smaller receptive fields allow finer spatial resolution.


Touch sensitivity is not uniform across the body.
Regions such as:

Fingertips

Lips

Have higher receptor density and smaller receptive fields.



Touch intensity is encoded by:

Firing rate

Number of activated receptors



Somatosensory information travels from:

Peripheral receptors

Through spinal nerves

Into the central nervous system

This information is organized and preserved along the pathway.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Two major somatosensory pathways


Somatosensory information reaches the brain through two main pathways.
They differ in:

The type of information they carry

Their anatomical routes

Their functional roles


The dorsal column pathway carries:

Fine touch

Vibration

Proprioception

This pathway supports precise spatial and discriminative touch.



In the dorsal column pathway:

Primary afferents enter the spinal cord

Ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns

Synapse in the medulla

Cross to the contralateral side

Project to the thalamus

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Spinothalamic pathway



The spinothalamic pathway carries:

Pain

Temperature

It is specialized for detecting potentially harmful stimuli.



In the spinothalamic pathway:

Primary afferents enter the spinal cord

Synapse almost immediately

Cross to the contralateral side near entry

Ascend to the thalamus




The two pathways differ in function:

Dorsal column
Precise, fast, spatially accurate
Spinothalamic
Coarser, slower, protective

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: Somatosensory Pathways

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Primary somatosensory cortex



Somatosensory information reaches primary somatosensory cortex (S1). S1 is located in the postcentral gyrus. It contains an ordered map of the body (Somatotopy).


Somatotopy means that:

Body position is mapped systematically

Neighboring body regions map to neighboring neural regions





The sensory homunculus is a distorted body map. Body parts with high sensory acuity occupy more cortical space. Hands, lips, and face are overrepresented.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cortical magnification and Lesions



Cortical representation does not reflect body size.
It reflects:

Receptor density

Behavioral relevance

This parallels foveal magnification in vision.



Lesions in somatosensory cortex produce:

Loss of sensation in specific body regions

Deficits that reflect the cortical map

The pattern of loss reveals underlying organization.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Pain as a distinct system

Pain is not simply strong touch. It is a distinct sensory system specialized for detecting potential or actual tissue damage. Its primary function is protection, not perception.




Pain begins at specialized receptors called nociceptors.
These receptors respond to:

Mechanical damage

Extreme temperatures

Chemical irritants

They are activated only when stimuli exceed safe limits and activate the Spinothalamic pathway.



Nociception is detected by Free Nerve Endings and there are two main fiber types:

Aδ fibers
Fast, sharp, well-localized pain
C fibers
Slow, dull, poorly localized pain

These produce different pain sensations.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Central processing of pain


Pain processing involves multiple brain regions.
These include:

Thalamus

Amygdala
Hyppocampus
Somatosensory cortex

Insular cortex

Anterior cingulate cortex

Prefrontal Cortex

Pain has both sensory and emotional components.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Pain is multidimensional



Pain includes:

Sensory-discriminative aspects

Affective-motivational aspects

Cognitive modulation




Phantom pain Pain can occur without peripheral input. Phantom pain arises after limb loss. This shows that pain is generated centrally, not only in the periphery.



Pain signals are not fixed.
They are modulated by:

Descending cortical control

Brainstem circuits

Context and expectation

Pain perception is dynamic.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The auditory system

Hearing allows the nervous system to detect and interpret sound. Sound is a pattern of pressure waves in airfrom 20 Hz to 20 kHz. Perception arises from how these waves are transformed into neural signals.









Sound waves are characterized by:

Frequency related to perceived pitch

Amplitude related to perceived loudness.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Anatomy of the ear



The auditory system converts:

Air pressure changes

Into mechanical vibrations

Into electrical signals

This transformation occurs in specialized structures of the ear.


The ear is divided into 3 main parts:

Outer ear

Middle ear

Inner ear

Each part performs a specific transformation.



The outer ear collects sound waves. The middle ear amplifies vibrations using 3 small bones. This amplification is essential for efficient sound transmission.


The inner ear contains the cochlea.
Inside the cochlea:

Sound vibrations create traveling waves

Different frequencies peak at different locations

This spatial separation is fundamental to hearing.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: Anatomy of the ear

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Hair cells



Sensory transduction occurs in the Coorti organ, where Hair Cells convert mechanical movement into electrical signals. They are true sensory receptors.


Movement of hair bundles opens mechanically gated ion channels.
This leads to:

Receptor potentials

Neurotransmitter release

Activation of auditory nerve fibers

Sound is now encoded neurally.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
From ear to brain

Brainstem

The first synapse occurs in the cochlear nuclei of the brainstem. Information is split into parallel pathways. Different aspects of sound are processed simultaneously.


The superior olivary complex is a key site for sound localization. It integrates input from both ears. Different nuclei specialize in timing and intensity comparisons.



From the brainstem, signals ascend through:

Inferior colliculus

Medial Geniculate Nucleus (Thalamus)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Interaural level differences



Interaural level differences arise from sound shadowing by the head. They are most informative for high-frequency sounds. These differences are computed in brainstem circuits.


The auditory system uses two main interaural cues:

Interaural time differences (due to speed of sound)
Interaural amplitude differences (due to the acoustic shadow)

Each cue is informative under different conditions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Primary auditory cortex
The primary auditory cortex is the first cortical stage of hearing. It is located in the temporal lobe. It receives organized input from the thalamus.



Primary auditory cortex is organized tonotopically: Neighboring neurons respond to neighboring sound frequencies.


Cortical magnification: Frequencies important for communication occupy more cortical space. Representation reflects behavioral relevance, not physical frequency spacing.



Damage to primary auditory cortex rarely causes deafness.
Instead, it impairs:

Sound discrimination

Complex auditory perception

Basic hearing often remains intact.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Beyond primary auditory cortex

Primary auditory cortex encodes basic acoustic features. However, hearing does not end in A1. Surrounding A1 are secondary auditory areas. These regions receive input from A1 and from the thalamus. They integrate information over longer time windows.




Higher-order areas respond to:

Frequency combinations

Temporal patterns

Sound sequences

These features are essential for speech and music.



Higher-order auditory cortex supports auditory objects. An auditory object is a coherent sound source over time. Like:

A voice

A melody

A moving sound

The brain groups sound features into perceptual units.
